name: Looking for help with a build, please.
author: Nephylos

posts.author: Nephylos
posts.content:
Hello all,
  I am looking to get back into playing NWN on the Arelith server, but this time I would like a character that doesn't suck. I am terrible at builds. I have always made characters with RP in mind, but then I realized that I can still RP and have a character that can hold up well in a fight (I tend to end up with characters that do very little damage and cannot protect themselves very well). I want the days of watching people my level or lower hammering out two or three times the damage output than me to be over, so I'm asking this forum for help! 
Some notes to help you help me:
- I don't do too well with spellcasting classes, but am not opposed to trying it. I am simply inexperienced with using them. I have used a bard successfully to some degree. 
- I am looking for a "spy" type build, so rogue/monk/shadowdancer might be ideal. This is NOT to say that I necessarily want a "stealth" build, but decent stealth would be helpful. Good Bluff, Listen, and Spot are desireable, and Lore if possible. 
- I am also hoping to dual wield (short swords?), so maybe ranger would fit in there somewhere? I have been reading that a monk with dual kamas is a popular choice, so maybe ranger levels are not necessary.
- Arelith has a level cap of 30, and when you multiclass, you must take 3 levels of the new class consecutively. 
- Some of the feats, spells, and classes have been changed, nerfed, or prohibited on Arelith. They have a wiki page you can glance at to see what they are: http://wiki.arelith.com/Arelith_Wiki

I think that's about all I can come up with. Obviously, I'll answer specific questions for anyone trying to help me, and I appreciate any and all help greatly! =)

posts.author: Stagmeister
posts.content:
Hi there, Nephylos - and welcome! There are some great builds and builders here, but I have to confess that I'm not one of them. However, I hope I can help in terms of guidance, if you'll bear with me until someone else comes along.

First off, I don't know Arelith, but I do know that there have been lots of requests for builds and guidance about that server. You'll find some polished, high quality ones in our Mid-Epic (level 30) forum. Always worth a look. There are also many Arelith-specific builds bouncing around in this particular sub-forum, so again, worth scanning through.

Weirdly, there are several conversations going on at the moment here about monk/rogue builds, so again...(you get the picture).

If these are your preferred classes (something between monk, rogue, ranger, SD), unless you're going for only minimal monk input, dual-wielding kamas seems to me to make more sense than anything. Some would say it's a cliche, but there has to be some restriction on the (to my mind) best class in the game. More attacks than you can shake a stick at, solid AC and AB - what's not to like? Sorry, getting carried away again. Essentially, what I'm saying is have a good old browse around the site and get a bit more "feel" for what you want to play - RP is an important factor in any build that isn't merely robotic.

I appreciate that you'd probably prefer a straight answer, but others are better at that than I am. Personally, I'm just really pleased you're here!

Cheers

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
I see katana can be finessed on Arelith but does it count as a light offhand weapon?  In vanilla NWN, a light weapon either needs to be one size smaller than the race holding it or the offhand end of a two-end weapon (i.e. a certain class of large weapons), else incur additional DW penalties. I see nothing within the wiki that redefines what a light weapon is.

Also, since you're delaying rogue levels well into pre-epic anyway, why not wait until 21-23 and gain an additional BAB? 

If you are serious about Discipline in a DEX build, you'll need to swap the Epic Focus from Spot to Discipline to do much good.  Not ideal, but better.

My own preference would be IKD instead of ImpExpertise.  Your AB isn't going be all that impressive and you can't taunt your way out of the attack penalty.

You'll have so little sneak damage, investing in stealth won't be all that significant.  Besides, with UMD you'll have access to Invis scrolls (or just use pots if they sell them).

You'll have somewhere around 210-220 skill points to play with.  In vanilla, you'd get an XP penalty from Level 11-30 but with a subrace system (or if the server just ignores XP penalty based on class) you might be able to avoid it.  Haven't a clue myself hoe Arelith handles these basic rules.

As you Arelith fans request build info with reliance on nuances, please continue to amend the topic created here specifically to provide some illumination for those of us committed to helping as best we can.  Then provide a linik to that topic, not the Arelith wiki or their forums.  It's not a matter of patience with me.  Just plain 'ol time left on the planet to do what I can in the duration alloted.

IKD has little to do with PvP, Rua.  It's to attempt KD on larger creatures and reduce the AB penalty overall. It may have a slight advantage in PvP vs. high Discipline STR builds but little else.  PvP vs. mages it will mean zilch unless they are polymorphed to Iron Golem or such.

Your ranger plan has the following attack/AC at level 30, DWing, assuming katana is considered a light offhand weapon:

+29/+24/+19/+14/+29/+24  AC24
+19/+14/+9/+4/+19/+14   AC34 (ImpExpertise mode)

If you can compete on this server without WF/EWF and a better boost to AC (usually Armor Skin serves the purpose adequately) then just about any build should work fine.  The AB is low even without figuring modal AC advantages.  You certainly will never crit any boss types... unless Arelith has also gimped those.  To think that you purposely discarded at least 4AB (that's 20% greater chance to hit!) is painful to consider.  The important factor is not damage per hit, but damage per round.  Roll those 20's!

Nephylos, to find out more about skill dumps. Read my Complete Guide to the Basics of Character Building in the game guides section.

Rua, if Katanas have been changed in Arelith, I have no way of knowing. The standard penalty for dual-wielding is -2 per attack, so you give up a bit of AB for more APR, but that only works if your offhand weapon is light, which means small for normal size and tiny for small size creatures. Otherwise that penatly is -4, which is kinda hefty if the monster ACs are competitive. Make sure that's the case and if so, please post wherever it is that Hip asked you to :).

About discipline, here's how it works. Suppose you're a level 30 characte with 55 AC. Being a DEXer, that's easily attainable. My level 40 DEXers have a MINIMUM of 65 AC hasted. Actually, the lowest AC I have is 66 in a +5 environment. You can reach 33 Ranks in Discipline, with +1 from your STR score, that's 34 + d20 = 54, which is still lower than your AC. Now, if you get attacked, it means that the guy rolled more than your AC, which is higher than your Discipline score, so you WILL FAIL the discipline check no matter what, does that make sense?

cheers!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
Nephylos, Bard's UMD works differently than rogue's or assassin's.  It doesn't run a hardcore scroll check so all you need to use all scrolls, arcane or divine, is enough to cover the scroll's value, with a value determined by the item's blueprint rather than the cost in a store.  Typically, net UMD 10 or 15 will cover this with room to spare.  Any additional UMD that a bard allocates is only to use class-specific items.  In that case you'd need to assure it falls on an increment of 5 after the skill dump, @20, 25, 30 etc.  With innate CHA less than 10, that means you'd need to delay your Tumble dump by a level or more (dwarven and half-orc UMD users usually must delay by 2 levels). 

Using Rua's ranger example (only because it's handy), the final rogue dump level should have been at Level 28, not 27.  At Level 27, UMD max would be 27 + 3 - 1(CHA 8) = UMD 29 whereas at 28 it is 28 + 3 - 1 = UMD 30.  UMD 29 enables exactly the same gear value as UMD 25 (600K gold).  Unless you are willing to use a gear slot to add CHA, an ability that should not factor into a build like this, make sure you get the result that was intended when schedulng skill dumps.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
To paste text from Excel to the editor, here's how I do it:
  • Select/hold and drag the cells of Column C of the CBC output sheet beginning with cell C6 through your last line of the skills section. (You'll notice the small white text box on the left just below the icon and menu bars displays the cell you have selected to start the drag.)
  • Key Ctrl-C (stuffs the data into the buffer).
  • Open Notepad, click inside and key Ctrl-V (pastes whatever was in the buffer into Notepad).
  • In Notepad, key Ctrl-A to re-select all you've pasted, then key Ctrl-C the second time to copy all selected from Notepad.
(I usually do some clean-up like removing extra whitespace beforehand directly in Notepad because for me it saves some time editting locally.)
The reason for the extra copy step is because Excel data contains formatting that Forumer's editor does not like very much.  Copying from Notepad strips all the formatting.
  • Then just click inside the Forumer editor and key Ctrl-V to paste the selected into the editor.
Finish up your final formatting in the editor and check the output with the Preview screen before posting.

Just for training purposes, turn your build design into an Epic Dodge version. 

Hints:  You only need Ranger 9 minimum for all dual-wield feats.  Epic Dodge requires at least either Rog10/Mnk9 or Rog13/MnkX, DEX 25 minimum and Tumble of 30 ranks.  The earliest you can achieve Epic Dodge is Level 27 because of the Tumble prereq.  It appears you can reach at least DEX 26 by build's end, maybe more (haven't juggled a sample myself but remember building an Epic Dodge DEXer for Arelith many moons ago so it can surely be done).  Epic Toughness is only a convenience for feat-flushed builds.  Too many feats in epic have greater impact than an extra 20HP (that's one heal pot or kit).

I have a few ideas how to better optimize this, but am just too foggy atm to piece something together.  So give it a whirl yourself and we'll compare notes when I'm fully conscious.  Deal?

posts.author: Maximillian Kane

Nephylos.Thank you for reading my guide and using my sheet as a guideline to build your toon.

If you're going for DEX, it's nearly always recommendable that you try to get Epic Dodge. It's simply THE BEST FEAT a DEXer can have.

Why do you focus so much on saves? You have Evasion, Monk has all saves strong, and you don't even take feats like Epic Weapon Focus, while taking Epic Will, Epic Fortitude and Epic Toughness (WOOT?).

If you want saves, my advice is to go for Monk / Rogue / CoT and MANUALLY TAKE the TWF feats instead of going Ranger. You'd get your saves boost from CoT and wouldn't need to take crappy Epic feats instead of good ones. You lose Ranger spells, and animal companion (meh).

High priority feats should be: TWF, Ambidexterity and ITWF (which you can get from Ranger or with CoT Bonus Feats), Epic Dodge (which needs 25 DEX, so you'd need to rearrange starting stats and epic feats to squeeze in 2 Great Dexterities), Armor Skin, Epic Weapon Focus (EWF).

Then if you have any spare feats, you can go ahead and take ONE Epic save feat. But only after you've fit in all your must-haves!

You didn't do too well on your first attempt. But yield not! Pick yourself up, dust yourself off and try again. We have your back, brother!

Between the sample builds posted and some tutelage from Max, you should be good to go.  Now it's just a matter of getting some testing done for the fine-tuning.

Just a note in passing, Nephylos...

The guild vets will always design around power-building or as close as we can come to it.  That's just our "calling", our speciality.

As an RPer, what your task becomes is to take our suggestions and modify it to suit YOUR purpose.  That will likely result in a power-drain of the build's potential, but roleplay is a bird of different-colored feathers.  It's of little value to show with a killer build only to find you are unable to interact with the server's community the way you would like to.  It still comes down to a comfort level as to whether you can implement the design's features as they were intended.  The most important lesson you can learn from our exposition is exactly what your modifications for roleplay considerations will cost you.  Obviously, if you end up failing in key combat encounters, you've overcompensated with your roleplay preferences and it's back to the drawing board for the next redress.  And that's how we all learn!

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
hunearo wrote:
Even a maxed discipline can be a waste of skillpoints for a dexer, probably you will need epic skill focus to make it work.
I'm going to disagree with this statement because it's still just an opposed skill check vs. AB.  An uber STR design can still roll low numbers and 1-20 is a huge disparity.  Just because the skill is not bolstered by the STR modifier does not mean it cannot be effective resisting combat feat threats that suffer AB penalties anyway.  Besides, since DEXers need not be concerned with AC or AB issues, it's more likely they will cap their STR via gear/buffs for weapon damage.  Add another +6 to the Discipline skill which is only 4 points of Discipline short of what Epic Discipline achieves.  4 points = 20%.  That still leaves 80% for successes.

The key is regular Discipline dumps so your toon doesn't lag behind the offending ABs too long.

Don't make the common mistake of assuming that every attacker attempting a combat feat has an AB lofty enough to guarantee success against a significant skill level especially vs. DEX AC.  There are two situations where an investment in Discipline has poor return on the investment for a DEXer:  1) only being able to xclass the skill and 2) small races (especially vs. KD and Disarm).  This build is neither, so the results in testing will support the value.  But don't take my word for it.  Run through a trainer with combat debugging on and prove it to yourself.  A couple hundred rounds or so spamming combat feats should do the trick.

posts.author: Maximillian Kane
posts.content:
Just to spice things up, allow me to disagree with Hip on this.

Hip, the reason for Discipline being close to useless to a DEXer is not due to enemy AB vs Discipline Check ratio. That is actually quite irrelevant IMO. The most important ratio you should have in mind is your own AC vs your max Discipline Check. That'll help you figure out how often your discipline will actually even come into play. If your AC is higher than your Discipline Check, you'll only ever use it when the enemy hits you on a natural 20. That's exactly 5% of the time. Even if your max discipline is slightly higher than your AC, that'll go up to 25% chance tops. And a 25% chance of it coming into play. You'd still need to ROLL a high number to be able to resist the combat feat being used on you. IMO Discipline for DEXers will only work in extremely low magic settings, where you can't get your AC high enough.

Take it EZ!

It's funny how this all boils down to philosophy. I look at each build as if it were a course. You can cheat to get the grades you need and graduate with a moderate proficiency in whatever skill you set out to learn. Or, you can endure the hard-fought path of actually pulling all-nighters studying and doing everything you can to actually come out of it knowing as much as possible about the subject. Now in this comparison, the knowledge you have upon graduation would be the level 40 power of your build. The "cheating" would be reducing the knowledge you have by getting the marks without actually learning the stuff, or in this case, taking away from the final result (level 40 power) to make the journey (leveling) easier.

So as a rule of thumb, I tend to make decisions that will increase the overall power of the build at level 40 when I'm building, which also makes me aware of the build's weaknesses when I'm playing it. Then, in-game, I try to compensate the weaknesses that I know the build has with intelligent decision-making. As an example, on a Fighter 10 / Dwarven Defender 26 / Rogue 4, it'd mean not taking Rogue until epics to maintain MAX pre-epic BAB. And so far, I've played many such builds. I've always been able to find a way to overcome the challenges I face with in-game decisions. And I've played some pretty gimped builds, such as Edwin Odeisseron (Wizard 29 / PM 10 / Assassin 1), whose only Tumble and UMD dumps were at level 37, or Nathyrra (Ranger 12 / Wizard 10 / Assassin 18), who is a concept build that really surprised me, as I expected to have a lot more trouble with  than I actually ended up having, because she was basically good at nothing, but once I figured out how to use the very few spells to the fullest, became a really strong "spell"sword. Spell is between quotes there because when you make a spellsword, you generally do it to cast high-level spells, whereas she only has the crappy ones LOL.

As for the NPCs rolling 20s 30% of the time, IDK if that can be scripted, but if it can, shame on the builders! So they can't make a decent AI script and they decide to cut corners by increasing the "luck factor"????? That sucks! But you'd still need to ROLL the required Discipline total to succeed. That's still a 25% success rate AT BEST! IDK about investing skill points with those odds. I think I wouldn't.

Take it EZ!

posts.content:
Maximillian Kane wrote:
As for the NPCs rolling 20s 30% of the time, IDK if that can be scripted, but if it can, shame on the builders! So they can't make a decent AI script and they decide to cut corners by increasing the "luck factor"????? That sucks! But you'd still need to ROLL the required Discipline total to succeed. That's still a 25% success rate AT BEST! IDK about investing skill points with those odds. I think I wouldn't.
 
That analogy is ludicrous but inventive, Max.  Every build must be played from start to finish so every level has its consequences in both being able to interact with the surroundings and in terms of combat effectiveness.  You just happen to possess a facination in seeing the final "paper" calculations reach fruition, much like an obsession, where others may want to just enjoy the build's performance through the entire process.  All those cheese monk-dump-at-40 builds and their ilk are for environments where the community can play specially-designed areas meant for capped PCs or PvP arenas for many hours after "maturity".  In any event, RP changes much of the rote optimization strategy.

As far as our divergent "philosophy" is concerned, it's very basic.  You are used to playing within environments where death has little consequence and use a design rationale that reflects that.  Just respawn and continue where you left off.  Make up for what's lost by sheer playing time.  I, on the other side of the philosophical coin, consider death a failed venture, as a product of playing on permadeath servers (those that have removed autofail/autosuccess mechanics) for several years, now defunct due to the lack of hardcore D&D players these days.

As I proposed earlier, to shorten this predictable and repetitive deliberation... we shall "agree to disagree" and allow the OP to make his own evaluation based on his own experience(s).  That's all that matters in the final analysis anyway.
 
It's simple to generically change the combat balance, btw, which is why Bioware used the method to adjust difficulty settings for SP.  Give the NPCs multiple d20 dice for every attack roll using the exact same ruleset and metrics as PvP.  Simple and clean.

Perhaps your idyllic dream could be realized if you spent some quality time designing the perfect AI yourself, one that performs to your expectations. I'm sure the community would laud your efforts. But it is easier to criticize than be proactive, I suppose.  Human nature.  Even in Brazil.

Now... back to our regularly-scheduled program that has something to do with helping a returning player achieve his goals on the Arelith server.  Apologies for the interruption, Nephylos.
